facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 134 of 1964 is an appeal by special leave from the judgement and order dated September 28, 1962, of the Bombay High Court in L. P. Appeal No. 85 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 134 of 1964 Appeal by special leave from the judgement and order dated September 28, 1962, of the Bombay High Court in L. P. Appeal No. 85 of 1961.

facts.text: Plaintiffs are tenants occupying different rooms in Dhobi Chawls also known as Colaba Land Mill Chawls on Lala Nigam Road, Colaba, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs are some of the tenants occupying different rooms in a group of buildings known as Dhobi Chawls  and also known as the Colaba Land Mill Chawls  situate on Lala Nigam Road, Colaba, Bombay-

facts.text: Plaintiffs instituted suit in representative capacity on behalf of all tenants in City Civil Court, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: There are a large number of other tenants also who reside or carry on business in these Chawls and the plaintiffs instituted a suit in a representative capacity on behalf of all the tenants.

facts.text: First defendant is Municipal Corporation of Greater Bombay, defendants 2 to 4 are landlords of the plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: The first defendant to the suit is the Municipal Corporation of Greater Bombay and the remainmg defendants 2 to 4 are landlords of the plaintiffs.

facts.text: Buildings and land belong to Colaba Land Mill Co., Ltd., Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The buildings and the land on which they stand belong to the Colaba Land Mill Co., Ltd., Bombay.

facts.text: Under agreement dated May 16, 1956 called Demolition Agreement, defendants 2 to 4 undertook to demolish buildings after permission of Rent Controller.

anchor.surface_text: Under an agreement dated May 16, 1956 called the Demolition Agreement defendants 2 to 4 undertook for a certain companysideration to demolish the buildings which are admittedly in a dilapidated companydition after taking the permission of the Rent Controller, Bombay.

facts.text: Under cl. 7 of agreement, defendants 2 to 4 put in possession with leave and licence of Company, liable to pay Rs. 20,221-8-0 p.a. till demolition, then tenants at will.

anchor.surface_text: Under cl. 7 of that agreement defendants 2 to 4 were to be put in possession of the buildings and land on which they stand, with leave and licence of the Company and were liable to pay Rs. 20,221-8-0 p.a. to the Company till the demolition of the buildings and thereafter they were to hold the land as tenants at will of the Company.

facts.text: Until demolition, defendants 2 to 4 entitled to rents from tenants, liable to pay monthly taxes, insurance premia and other dues.

anchor.surface_text: Until the demolition of the buildings, defendants 2 to 4 were entitled to the rents payable by the tenants occupying the buildings and were liable to pay monthly taxes, insurance premia and other dues payable in respect of the buildings.

facts.text: After demolition, defendants 2 to 4 entitled to materials and debris but pay Rs. 40,000 to Company, paid Rs. 10,000 at time of agreement.

anchor.surface_text: After the demolition of the buildings defendants 2 to 4 were entitled to all the materials and debris but had to pay Rs. 40,000 as the price thereof to the Company. Out of this amount these defendants had to pay and had actually paid Rs. 10,000 at the time of the agreement.

facts.text: Buildings in dilapidated condition for number of years, 138 notices served on Company between August 1951 and May 1956 for repairs, no action.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs companytention is that the buildings were in a dilapidated companydition for a number of years and that between August 1951 and May 1956 as many as 138 numberices were served on the Company for effecting repairs to the buildings but they took numberaction whatsoever in this regard.

facts.text: Between November 1956 and January 29, 1960, eleven notices served on defendants 2 to 4 for repairs, no action.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs further say that between November 1956 and January 29, 1960, eleven numberices were served on defendants 2 to 4 for the same purpose but numberaction was taken by them either on those numberices.

facts.text: Company and defendants 2 to 4 prosecuted 71 times for non-complying with notices, prosecutions ineffective.

anchor.surface_text: Further the Company and defendants 2 to 4 were prosecuted 71 times for number companyplying with the numberices but even these prosecutions proved ineffective.

facts.text: Corporation declared area as clearance area under S. 354R and made clearance order under S. 354RA, confirmed by State Government.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs admit that the Corporation, in exercise of the powers companyferred by S. 354R of the Bombay Municipal Corporation Act, 1888  hereafter referred to as the Act  have declared the area in which the buildings stand as a clearance area and under s. 354RA of that Act made a clearance order which has been duly companyfirmed by the State Government.

facts.text: Clearance order made by Corporation on May 7, 1959, confirmed by State Government on January 23, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: bearing in mind the fact that the clearance order was made by the Corporation as long ago as May 7, 1959 and companyfirmed by the State Government on January 23, 1960

facts.text: Trial court dismissed the suit as not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt dismissed the suit mainly upon the ground that it war, number tenable.

facts.text: Appeal to High Court dismissed summarily by Datar J. on August 25, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal was taken by the plaintiffs to the High Court which was dismissed summarily by Datar J., on August 25, 1961.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal No. 85 of 1961 before Division Bench of Patel and Palekar JJ.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day the plaintiffs preferred an appeal under the letters patent which went up before a Division Bench companysisting of Patel and Palekar JJ.

facts.text: Division Bench permitted amendment to plaint, held suit not barred, remitted case to City Civil Court for additional evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges permitted the plaintiffs to amend the plaint overruling the objections of the defendants. In their judgment the learned Judges held that the suit was number barred. ... Eventually, the learned Judges remitted the case to the, City Civil Court for recording additional evidence

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave to appellants, stayed proceedings before City Civil Court.

anchor.surface_text: After the grant of special leave to the appellants the proceedings before the City Civil Court have been stayed.

facts.text: Supreme Court set aside High Court judgment, allowed appeal, held suit not maintainable.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly we set aside the judgment of the High Court and allow this appeal.

facts.text: Landlords constructed chawls at Kurla, offered to house tenants temporarily.

anchor.surface_text: It is number disputed before us that the landlords had companystructed some chawls at Kurla and that they had offered to house the tenants of the Dhobi Chawls in the Kurla Chawls temporarily.

facts.text: Landlords agreed to construct new buildings after demolition for present tenants at standard rents.

anchor.surface_text: It was also number disputed that the landlords had agreed to companystruct, after the demolition work was over, new buildings in which the present tenants would be afforded accommodation at standard rents.

facts.text: City Engineer letter dated September 3, 1959 to Tenants Association stating landlords agreed to construct single room tenements at standard rents and provide alternative accommodation.

anchor.surface_text: the letter, dated September 3, 1959 which the City Engineer wrote to the Tenants Association and the letter, dated September 11, 1959 which the Commissioner wrote to the Improvements Committee.

facts.text: City Engineer letter dated April 1, 1960 to Tenants Association reaffirming landlord responsibility for alternative accommodation.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court had apparently in mind the letter, dated April 1, 1960 sent by the City Engineer to the Tenants Association which is described in the paper book as item No. 38.

facts.text: Plaintiffs contended sections 354R and 354RA ultra vires Articles 19(1)(f) and (g).

anchor.surface_text: According to them, however, these provisions are ultra vires of Arts. 19   1    f  and  g  ,of the Constitution.

According to them, however, these provisions are ultra vires of Arts. 19   1    f  and  g  ,of the Constitution.

holdings.text: The High Court was not justified in permitting the amendment to the plaint as it introduced a new case of fraud without basis in the original plaint.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of the view that the High Court was in error in allowing the amendment to the plaint and in remitting the suit to the trial court for a virtual retrial.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amendment shifts grounds to fraud and denial of responsibility not supported by original 'mala fide' allegation which related to unconstitutionality and lack of hearing; mere word 'mala fide' insufficient basis.

holdings.text: There is no basis or prima facie evidence of fraud or mala fides by defendants 2-4 or the Corporation from the documents on record.

anchor.surface_text: How this letter can afford any evidence of fraud or mala fides it is difficult to appreciate. It is not disputed before us that the landlords had constructed some chawls at Kurla...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Letters from City Engineer reaffirm landlords' agreement for alternative accommodation at standard rents and temporary housing; no indication of going back on assurances or collusion; deliberate neglect of repairs does not prove fraud.

holdings.text: The High Court erred in directing additional evidence and remitting the case as it amounted to a fresh trial, not permitted under O. XLI r. 27 CPC.

anchor.surface_text: If the High Court, in making these observations, was referring to the provisions of 0. XLI, r. 27, Code of Civil Procedure it ought not to have overlooked the mandatory provisions...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Additional evidence only to fill lacuna or enable judgment, not for unexplained documents already on record or to support prima facie inference; direction for specific witnesses and written statements indicates retrial.

holdings.text: High Court did not proceed under O. XLI r. 25 or r. 23 CPC for remand.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has quite clearly not proceeded under 0. XLI, r. 25 because it has not come to the conclusion... preliminary point and, therefore, a general remand such as is permissible under r. 23 could not

holdings.reasoning_summary: No omitted issue or preliminary point decided by trial court; not for framing additional issue or general remand.

holdings.text: Tenant's interest in premises is 'property' under Art. 19(1)(f), subject to reasonable restrictions under Art. 19(5).

anchor.surface_text: We have no doubt that a tenant has both under the Transfer of Property Act and under S. 12 of the Bombay Rents... an interest in the demised premises which squarely falls within... Art. 19

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under TPA and Bombay Rents Act s.12, tenant has protected interest qualifying as property; but right subject to public interest restrictions.

holdings.text: Sections 354R and 354RA of BMC Act are not ultra vires Arts. 19(1)(f) and (g); impose reasonable restrictions.

anchor.surface_text: It follows from this that the restrictions on the tenants right to hold property enacted by ss. 354R and 354RA are not unreasonable and that the provisions are valid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Provisions require notice publication inviting objections from affected persons including tenants, service on owners, consideration of objections, and appeal right; ensures minimal hardship.

holdings.text: Tenants are 'any person aggrieved' under cl. 2 Schedule GG, entitled to appeal clearance order to City Civil Court Judge.

anchor.surface_text: The expression any person aggrieved is sufficiently wide to include not only a tenant but also an occupant... The natural meaning would certainly include a person whose interest is affected

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide amplitude of 'any person aggrieved'; natural meaning includes those affected like tenants/occupants; supported by precedents; right to object via publication and appeal post-confirmation.

holdings.text: Provisions of ss. 354R-354RA and Sch GG satisfy natural justice by providing opportunity to tenants to object and appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 4 reads thus Before submitting the order to the State Government, the Commissioner shall- a publish simultaneously... b serve on every person... objections thereto

holdings.reasoning_summary: Publication invites objections from affected (incl. tenants); service on owners; objections considered; appeal as aggrieved person; publication post-confirmation with appeal right.

holdings.text: No evidence of mala fides by Municipal Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: No particulars of mala fides have, however, been set out in the plaint... documents do not support

holdings.reasoning_summary: No particulars pleaded; documents show no abuse; deliberate neglect by owners/landlords does not indicate Corporation collusion.

holdings.text: Suit not maintainable as barred by cl. 2 Schedule GG after failure to exhaust statutory appeal remedy.

anchor.surface_text: The question which falls for decision... is whether the suit instituted by the plaintiffs in the City Civil Court, Bombay, was maintainable. ... Agreeing with the learned City Civil Court Judge we hold that the plaintiffs suit was not maintainable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tenants as aggrieved persons had appeal right under cl.2 Sch GG; finality post-appeal or dismissal; no suit remedy available.

precedents.citation: Ex parte Sidebotham, In re Sidebotham. 1 1880 14 Ch.D. 458 at p. 465
precedents.case_name: Ex parte Sidebotham, In re Sidebotham
precedents.cited_proposition: natural meaning of 'person aggrieved' includes a person whose interest is in any manner affected by the order
